I.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 
1.  The proposed Mortgage Market Sector Development Program  will help establish a 
market-based housing finance sector in Uzbekistan, expand product availability and improve 
access to mortgage finance. The program will (i) undertake some of the most urgent housing 
policy, regulatory, and legal reforms; (ii) strengthen the institutional structure for a more efficient 
housing policy and subsidy framework; and (iii) make long-term fixed-rate local currency funds 
available through a sustainable mechanism and with reduced costs. The program will also assist 
the government in the identification of alternative and more efficient ways to provide subsidies to 
low-income families and improve access to long-term finance for underserved borrowers. In order 
to effectively support the housing finance sector reforms, the sector development program will 
combine a policy-based loan (PBL) and a financial intermediation loan. The PBL will support 
policy actions, while the financial intermediation loan will support the operationalization of the 
proposed Uzbekistan Mortgage Refinancing Company (UMRC) by providing long-term funding to 
the company. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
 
2.  The proposed transaction technical assistance (TA) is being processed at the request of 
the Government of Uzbekistan to advise the implementation of its housing sector reforms, 
including through the identification of targeted policy actions to be supported under the sector 
development program.  The program is intended to enhance the efficiency, and accelerate the 
implementation, of the government’s reform program..1 The Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
discussed the results framework, implementation arrangements, cost estimates, and scope of the 
transaction TA  with the government during the fact-finding mission from 27 to 29 May 2019.2 
 
3.  The transaction TA will have the following outcomes: (i) capacity of the key institutions 
strengthened in relation to housing policies, housing subsidies, and mortgage finance; (ii) the 
government’s implementation of the proposed policy actions under the second tranche of the PBL 
supported; and (iii) the underwriting and monitoring capacity of the UMRC improved. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
4.  Output 1: New housing policy and subsidy framework prepared. The transaction TA 
will advise the preparation of a new housing policy and subsidy framework targeting low- to 
middle-income beneficiaries. The new framework will introduce a transparent and empirical 
methodology for the identification of beneficiaries, facilitate performance monitoring, and support 
the design of sustainable interventions. This will include the design of a pilot program to introduce 
income-based  up-front  housing  subsidies  for  low-income  groups  (including  women-headed 
households), and preparation of a feasibility study to introduce new government-sponsored 
housing assistance schemes that can leverage market-based mortgage lending. 
 
5.  Output 2: Comprehensive housing and mortgage market database developed and 
made  accessible  via  the  web.  The  transaction  TA  will  advise  the  development  of  a 
comprehensive mortgage market database, which will  be made publicly available (in the form of

2    
 
 
a user-friendly website) to relevant government agencies, mortgage lenders, insurers, realtors, 
investors, and other stakeholders. This will provide consolidated information on, among others, 
the  number,  type,  and  size  of  mortgage  loans;  borrower  characteristics  (including  sex-
disaggregated data); loan-to-value ratios; house prices of mortgaged properties; and loan default 
data. Support to the State Statistics Committee will also be provided to assist in the preparation 
and approval of a new system for the collection and dissemination of timely data and information 
on household incomes and the housing sector, which will ultimately lead to the establishment of 
a house price index. 
 
6.  Output 3: Decision by the government to transform the Housing Assistance Unit 
into an independent housing agency supported. The transaction TA will help prepare a 
concrete implementation plan and schedule (with time-bound milestones and budget implications) 
on how to transform the Housing Assistance Unit (HAU) into an independent housing agency that 
can develop, coordinate, and manage all housing subsidy programs in Uzbekistan. Moreover, an 
impact assessment, with the view to abolish the current tax exemptions for developers and 
construction companies, will be carried out in collaboration with the HAU and the State Tax 
Committee. 
 
7.  Output 4: Current prudential and regulatory framework governing housing finance 
and  mortgage  lending  reviewed  and  amended.  A  review  of  the  current  prudential  and 
regulatory  framework  governing  housing  finance  and  mortgage  lending  and  recommended 
revisions will be conducted, drawing on international best practice. In addition, a legislative 
package will be prepared in collaboration with the government and the Central Bank of Uzbekistan 
(CBU) that will (i) allow mortgages pledged to wholesale lenders (such as mortgage refinancing 
companies) to be ring-fenced from other creditors in case of bankruptcy of the financial institution; 
(ii) enable the use of the zakladnaya instrument (mortgage certificates)  for eventual securitization 
of  (pools of) mortgages (i.e. certifying the rights created under a pool of rather than a single 
mortgage agreement); and (iii) revise the existing regulations to allow for pension funds in 
Uzbekistan to invest in highly rated and liquid debt securities, including those issued by wholesale 
lenders (such as mortgage refinancing companies). Finally, the Agency for Capital Market 
Development will be assisted in amending the relevant regulations on the issuance of securities 
to introduce the framework of shelf registrations for the issuance of bonds, and the CBU will be 
supported in its aim of improving and operationalizing the central electronic registry for pledged 
financial assets to facilitate the registration and search of the rights to mortgage portfolios. 
 
8.  Output 5: Areas and initiatives to promote demand- and supply-side competition in 
the housing market identified. A review of the demand and supply side of the housing market 
in Uzbekistan will be conducted to identify areas and initiatives to promote more competition by 
introducing  commercial  practices  based  on  international  best  practice  and  experience. 
Additionally, a feasibility study will be prepared on the future role and responsibilities of the two 
dominant state-owned real estate developers, Qishloq Qurilish Invest and Shahar Qurilish Invest, 
in collaboration with the Ministry of Finance (MOF) and the Antimonopoly Committee. 
 
9.  Output 6: The underwriting and monitoring capacity of the Uzbekistan Mortgage 
Refinancing Company improved. Under this output, the UMRC’s capacity in mortgage loan 
underwriting and monitoring will be strengthened by working closely with the operational and 
credit units of the company. The transaction TA will provide hands-on support to the credit officer(s) 
and refinance business officer(s) of the UMRC, and will guide, coach, and train them on all 
business processes (including handling requests for a refinance loan from a bank, undertaking 
the due diligence process of the prospective bank, processing the approval and disbursement of 
funding, and monitoring existing refinance lines until the loan is fully repaid).

3 
10.  Output 7: Gender sensitivity analysis supported. The transaction TA will support 
gender sensitivity analysis of the various housing finance programs of the government and the 
refinancing program of the UMRC, and assist in the creation of a specialized sex-disaggregated 
database. 
 
11.  Output 8: Trainings and workshops carried out. The transaction TA will provide 
support for trainings and workshops of various government ministries and agencies involved in 
the design and implementation of housing policies and subsidies, collection of related statistics, 
and broader engagement in mortgage market development. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $850,000, of which $800,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 1. 
 
13.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
accommodation and supplies, interdepartmental coordination, other logistical support and in-kind 
contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The implementation arrangements for the transaction TA will be aligned to those of the 
PBL. ADB’s Central and West Asia Department will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants 
and procure goods (if necessary). The MOF will be the executing agency. The CBU, State 
Statistics Committee, Antimonopoly Committee, Ministry of Economy and Industry, UMRC, and 
HAU under the MOF are proposed to be the implementing agencies. The program director from 
the HAU under the MOF will supervise overall implementation coordination across the various 
implementing agencies. The TA will be implemented from January 2020 to December 2021. 
 
15.  Individual consultants and a consulting firm will be engaged by ADB following the ADB 
Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and ADB’s staff instructions.3 ADB will 
select the consulting firm through the quality- and cost-based selection method with a standard 
quality–cost ratio of 90:10. The estimated consultant inputs comprise 18 person-months of 
international consulting services and 25 person-months of national consulting services. The 
bidders  may  suggest  some  adjustments,  with  justification.  Depending  on  the  emerging 
circumstances, the Central and West Asia Department team administering the TA will retain 
flexibility on the number and person-month allocations among the experts as well as their tasks. 
An overview of the required consulting services is provided in the table.
